questions.question_text: What is a difference between Chef and other automation tools?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
Chef uses agent and Ruby.

Selected Answer: C
Given answer is correct

Selected Answer: C
https://learningnetwork.cisco.com/s/question/0D56e0000CwDQqvCQG/what-is-chef

Chef uses different terminology to Puppet. Instead of modules and manifests, Chef has cookbooks and recipes.

A kitchen is an environment where recipes and cookbooks are tested before deployment.

Selected Answer: C
C: is correct 
Chef is agent based tool that uses cookbooks

choices.C: Chef is an agent-based tool that uses cookbooks, and Ansible is an agentless tool that uses playbooks.
choices.A: Chef is an agentless tool that uses playbooks, and Ansible is an agent-based tool that uses cookbooks.
choices.B: Chef is an agentless tool that uses a primary/minion architecture, and SaltStack is an agent-based tool that uses a primary/secondary architecture
choices.D: Chef uses Domain Specific Language, and Puppet uses Ruby.

questions.question_text: An engineer must configure a new WLAN that supports 802.11r and requires users to enter a passphrase. What must be configured to support this requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
802.11r is FT -- so It is A or B
But A requires users to authenticate not only with password, but with username also, and PSK indicates PreSharedKey.
B should be the correct answer
https://blogs.cisco.com/networking/what-is-802-11r-why-is-this-important

Selected Answer: B
Fast Transition (FT), often referred to as 802.11r, allows wireless clients to seamlessly switch between access points (APs) within the same WLAN without any noticeable interruption in connectivity. This significantly improves the user experience, especially for mobile users or applications sensitive to network disruptions.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
option D is incorrect because SUITEB-1X suggests the use of enterprise authentication mechanisms, not a pre-shared key (passphrase). The correct setup for using a passphrase and supporting 802.11r is to configure FT PSK and Fast Transition, as indicated in option B.

Selected Answer: B
To support a WLAN that utilizes 802.11r (Fast Transition) and requires users to enter a passphrase, so that will be:

B. FT PSK and Fast Transition

FT PSK stands for Fast Transition Pre-Shared Key, which allows for seamless roaming between access points without reauthentication, while still utilizing a passphrase for authentication. Fast Transition (802.11r) enables fast handoffs between access points within the same mobility domain, enhancing the mobility experience for wireless clients.
Hello Moderators, it would be kind if you could offer the Cisco documentation where the answer you chose exists. Sincerely, A learner.

Selected Answer: B
Correct answer is B

choices.C: Set MFP client protection to Required.
choices.D: Change NAC state to ISE NAC.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer is troubleshooting an mDNS issue in an environment where Cisco ISE is used to dynamically assign mDNS roles to users. The engineer has confirmed that ISE is sending the correct values, but name resolution is not functioning as expected. Which WLC configuration change resolves the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is A. Enable AAA Override.

AAA Override is a feature that allows the Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) to use the attributes returned from the RADIUS server via Access-Accept message to override the configuration on the WLC. When AAA Override is enabled and the WLC is integrated with Cisco ISE, it allows for dynamic VLAN assignments, QoS, ACLs, and mDNS (Bonjour) profiles on a per-user basis.

In this case, enabling AAA Override would allow the WLC to apply the mDNS roles assigned by ISE to the users, which should resolve the issue with mDNS name resolution. The other options (B, C, D) are not directly related to mDNS role assignment or name resolution. Therefore, they would not resolve the issue.

Selected Answer: A
The answer is enable AAA Overide.
On the controller, enable the Allow AAA Override configuration parameter using the GUI or CLI. Enabling
this parameter allows the controller to accept the attributes returned by the RADIUS server. The controller
then applies these attributes to its clients.

comments.content: There is no cisco documentation. They use ChatGPT lol

Speaking of ChatGPT:
Given the scenario where Cisco ISE is used to dynamically assign mDNS roles to users, and the issue is with name resolution not functioning as expected despite ISE sending correct values, the most relevant configuration option to consider on the Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) is likely to be: Changing NAC State to ISE NAC.

By changing the NAC state to ISE NAC, you are ensuring a more comprehensive integration with Cisco ISE, which could potentially resolve issues related to dynamic role assignments and permissions influencing name resolution.

I'm going with D.
Disregard this I think it's most likely Enable AAA Override now, one of the earlier questions about ISE functioning correctly with WLC required enabling it too.

questions.question_text: What is one role of the VTEP in a VXLAN environment?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
Option C functionality is associated with LISP, not VXLAN. In LISP, EID (Endpoint Identifier) to RLOC (Routing Locator) mapping is a key function. VXLAN does not use EID-to-RLOC mapping. Instead, it uses VTEPs to encapsulate and decapsulate VXLAN packets.

comments.content: ITR is the answer to C.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I think it might be C. Its more specific and it states a crucial function of VTEP. I dont like how D is worded. Im unsure though.

Selected Answer: D
virtual tunnel endpoint (VTEP) An entity that originates or terminates a VXLAN tunnel. It 
maps Layer 2 and Layer 3 packets to the VNI to be used in the overlay network.

Selected Answer: D
VTEP = VXLAN Tunnel Endpoint = what switch to tunnel traffic to, for delivery to that IP / MAC (computer).
https://netcraftsmen.com/sd-access-flows-registration-and-same-fabric-forwarding/
vtep encapsulates/decapsulates VXLANs

DRAG DROP
-

Drag and drop the snippets onto the blanks within the code to construct a script that configures BGP according to the topology. Not all options are used, and some options may be used twice.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Given answer is correct.
65001
182.168.1.1
65000
192.168.1.1
https://www.noction.com/blog/bgp-yang-next-generation

the router id is an IP address. 

ref: https://iosxr-lab-ciscolive.github.io/LTRSPG-2414-cleur2019/wkinstructions/2019-02-01-step-5-playing-iosxr-Yang-Models/
should be

comments.content: Wouldnt the last one also be .1 since its calling out neighbor again?
You are right, the last then also has to .1
That is what I was saying, it should be .1

discussion.content:
This was the very first question on my ENCOR v1.1 first attempt in March 2024, with slightly different options, the option 'ISP' and 'Client' were available.
There is no explicit configuration that suggests we should be configuring the client. If you guess that you are configuring the client router, the answers are:
192.168.1.2
192.168.1.1
65000
192.168.1.1
How can we derive the router to configure is the client other than 'us' not being a service provider? This creative approach is comical, as a network engineer the derivation has to be explicit - Imagine writing an RFC for a new company you have joined and you guessed you should be configuring a router called client, then you found out that you were actually an ISP but your onboarding was so poor than no one told you this

comments.content:
Having reviewed this link I believe kaupz given answer is now correct:
https://www.noction.com/blog/bgp-yang-next-generation

discussion.content:
given ans is correct
First blank (BGP ID for the router): The Client's AS is 65001, so this will go in the first blank.

Second blank (Neighbor ID): The neighbor is the ISP with IP 192.168.1.1 (ISP’s IP).

Third blank (Remote AS for neighbor): The ISP’s AS is 65000, so this goes in the third blank.

Fourth blank (BGP ID for the neighbor under IPv4): This is again the ISP’s IP 192.168.1.1.
I agree with IgorLVG
which authority is the best certification company?

IgorLVG had the correct idea but he messed up in the last answer. The last one should be 192.168.1.1. Storcaks is not the correct answer. The question tells us not all answers are used and some are used more than once which is exactly what happened. the id is the ip address, not the AS.

Correct answer (assuming we are configuring the left router) is:
192.168.1.2
192.168.1.1
65000
192.168.1.1

comments.content: In BGP configuration, <ios-bgp:id> under the <ios-bgp:bgp> tag refers to the AS number of the local router.

discussion.content: correct
Where did you guys get the hint that we're configuring from the client router?

comments.content: The exam is Enterprise Core so we are the Enterprise/Client not the Service Provider. And the answer is correct.
That is really a piece of creative logic.. after so many questions proving otherwise:)

No, answer is correct ... on client router
router bgp 65001
neighbor 192.168.1.1 remote-as 65000 
address family ipv4 ... neighbor 192.168.1.1

discussion.content: correct
